Apple___Apple_scab.description: Apple scab is a fungal disease caused by Venturia inaequalis that affects apple trees and their fruit. It's one of the most serious diseases of apple trees worldwide.
Apple___Apple_scab.symptoms: Dark, scaly lesions on leaves and fruit. Leaves may yellow and drop prematurely. Fruit develops dark, corky spots that can crack.
remedies: Apply fungicides containing sulfur or copper during early spring
Remove and destroy infected leaves and fruit from around trees
Improve air circulation by proper pruning
Apply dormant oil in early spring before bud break

Apple___Black_rot.description: Black rot is a fungal disease caused by Botryosphaeria obtusa that affects apple trees, causing leaf spots, fruit rot, and cankers.
Apple___Black_rot.symptoms: Brown to black circular spots on leaves with purple borders. Infected fruit develops dark, sunken lesions and may mummify on the tree.
remedies: Remove and destroy infected plant parts immediately
Apply preventive fungicides in early spring
Ensure proper drainage around tree base
Remove mummified fruit from trees and ground

Apple___Cedar_apple_rust.description: Cedar apple rust is a fungal disease caused by Gymnosporangium juniperi-virginianae that alternates between cedar/juniper trees and apple trees.
Apple___Cedar_apple_rust.symptoms: Bright yellow spots on upper leaf surfaces that develop orange, tube-like structures. Leaves may drop prematurely, reducing tree vigor.
remedies: Remove nearby cedar or juniper trees if possible
Apply fungicides during wet spring periods

Apple___healthy.description: The apple plant appears healthy with no visible signs of disease. Healthy apple trees have vibrant green foliage and proper growth patterns.
Apple___healthy.symptoms: Green, unblemished leaves with no spots, discoloration, or abnormal growth patterns. Normal fruit development if in season.
remedies: Monitor regularly for early disease detection
Ensure adequate sunlight and air circulation
Practice preventive care during disease-prone seasons

Corn_(maize)___Cercospora_leaf_spot.description: Cercospora leaf spot is a fungal disease caused by Cercospora zeae-maydis that affects corn plants, particularly in warm, humid conditions.
Corn_(maize)___Cercospora_leaf_spot.symptoms: Small, rectangular gray or tan spots with dark reddish-brown borders on leaves. Spots may merge to form large blighted areas.
remedies: Apply fungicides containing strobilurin or triazole
Practice crop rotation with non-host crops
Remove and destroy crop debris after harvest
Plant resistant corn varieties when available
Ensure proper plant spacing for air circulation

Corn_(maize)___Common_rust.description: Common rust is a fungal disease caused by Puccinia sorghi that creates characteristic rust-colored pustules on corn leaves.
Corn_(maize)___Common_rust.symptoms: Small, reddish-brown to golden pustules scattered on both leaf surfaces. Pustules may rupture and release orange spores.
remedies: Apply fungicides if infection becomes severe
Ensure proper plant spacing for air circulation
Monitor weather conditions - disease spreads in cool, humid weather

Corn_(maize)___Northern_Leaf_Blight.description: Northern leaf blight is a fungal disease caused by Exserohilum turcicum that produces elongated lesions on corn leaves.
Corn_(maize)___Northern_Leaf_Blight.symptoms: Long, elliptical gray-green to tan lesions with dark borders on leaves. Lesions may merge and cause significant leaf damage.
remedies: Apply fungicides containing azoxystrobin or propiconazole
Practice crop rotation with non-host crops for 2-3 years
Manage crop residue by tillage or chopping

Corn_(maize)___healthy.description: The corn plant appears healthy with normal growth and development. Healthy corn plants have upright, green leaves and proper development.
Corn_(maize)___healthy.symptoms: Green, upright leaves with no lesions, spots, or discoloration. Normal plant height and ear development for the growth stage.
remedies: Monitor for pest and disease pressure regularly
Ensure proper plant spacing and population
Scout fields regularly during growing season

Tomato___Bacterial_spot.description: Bacterial spot is caused by Xanthomonas species and affects tomato plants, causing leaf spots and fruit lesions.
Tomato___Bacterial_spot.symptoms: Small, dark brown spots with yellow halos on leaves. Fruit develops raised, scaly spots that may crack.

Tomato___Early_blight.description: Early blight is a fungal disease caused by Alternaria solani that affects tomato plants throughout the growing season.
Tomato___Early_blight.symptoms: Dark brown spots with concentric rings on older leaves. Lesions may have yellow halos and cause leaf yellowing.
remedies: Remove lower leaves touching the ground
Water at soil level, not on leaves

Tomato___Late_blight.description: Late blight is a devastating fungal disease caused by Phytophthora infestans that can destroy entire tomato crops.
Tomato___Late_blight.symptoms: Water-soaked spots on leaves that turn brown. White fuzzy growth may appear on leaf undersides in humid conditions.
remedies: Apply fungicides at first sign of disease

Tomato___healthy.description: The tomato plant appears healthy with vigorous growth and no visible disease symptoms.
Tomato___healthy.symptoms: Green, healthy foliage with no spots or discoloration. Normal fruit development and plant growth.
